Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: OCT-Compatible Imaging Adaptor for Precision Vascular Access via Hollow-Bore Needles
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project will develop a novel imaging adapter to temporarily integrate imaging into any needle or probe, enabling clinicians to visualize and identify anatomical markers in-situ, via real-time visualization, to improve vascular access without major modification of existing needles and technique. Venipuncture is the most common invasive procedure in medicine. Despite this, failure rates are 20-30% in easy access patients and 45-70% in difficult populations. Initial failed access leads to complications, increased hospital cost and poor patient outcomes. The proposed adapter represents a distinctive shift away from the way image guidance is currently used and several elements make this integrated, forward imaging system a transformative improvement: 1. It does not fundamentally change the standard procedural technique; 2. it improves image comprehension by ensuring the clinicians will always know what they are imaging (i.e. directly in front of the needle) drastically reducing complications caused by the needle penetrating the anatomy surrounding the target vessel, and; 3. The adapter will provide 10x better resolution than current imaging aids such as ultrasound. The proposed adapter will improve care of patients and significantly reduce healthcare costs by improving first time access success rates, reducing procedure complications, failures and escalations.

Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT), is a recognized transformative imaging aid. Data suggests that integrated tip-sourced imaging with OCT drastically improves both patient safety and outcomes by allowing the physician real-time decision-making capabilities for minimally invasive procedures. However, there has been no commercially successful market penetration of forward looking needle-based OCT imaging technology. There are a number of reason for this: 1) the challenge of acquiring clinically relevant images; 2) the cost and the challenge of developing a system that economically puts OCT at the tip of a needle; and 3) the challenge of clinical usability. The project will address these concerns with the development of a disposable OCT-based imaging adapter. Five significant technical challenges will be addressed: ensuring correct placement of the probe at the tip of the needle after connection and advancement; incorporating scanning at the fiber tip in order to acquire two dimensional clinically relevant, forward facing images; determining the optimal angle of light projection from the probe; determining the optimal universal lens tip design for cost and ease of advancement through tissue; and lastly, integrating key research finding into a final probe design that will become the basis of the commercialized adapter. Solving these technical challenges will pave the way for FDA approval and subsequent commercialization of the device.

POR.DRECONTENT:
WestFace Medical's SingleStickTM is a transformative device that uses optical coherence tomography (OCT) to enable tip-sourced imaging from within a needle used for pediatric vascular access. The SingleSticktm is designed to improve outcomes, lower costs, and increase patient (and clinician) satisfaction. The device consists of four components, that collectively are at the heart of the innovation:

  1. Disposable Imaging Adapter: The patented adapter integrates directly into the hollow bore of needle, providing imaging directly from the needle tip
  2. Non-disposable handpiece: allows for the scanning that enables real-time imaging and allows advancement and retraction of the imaging probe
  3. Imaging processor: The OCT laser and image processing equipment.
  4. Touchscreen tablet: The tablet displays real-time imaging of the tissue and anatomy allowing the clinician to target and successfully cannulate the vessel on the first attempt.

By temporarily integrating imaging into the needle used to obtain IV access (a fundamental change in the way imaging is currently used), clinicians are able to manipulate the needle and engage patients as they are accustomed to, but with the added benefit of seeing what is directly in front of the needle. This is especially important in pediatric practice. The SingleStickTM aims to facilitate first-time every-time access by solving the two major challenges of pediatric PIV access:

  1. Helping clinicians find the vein and adjust the angle and trajectory of the needle appropriately.
  2. By improving successful cannulation of the vessel and placement of the catheter with minimal damage to the vessel.

Phase I NSF SBIR funding was used to solve a number of technical challenges, and the team has designed a working prototype based on the findings. Moreover, the development was done within the constraints of producing a disposable adapter that could ultimately be commercialized for a cost of goods (COGS) of $5.

Initially, the team needed to develop a small beam-scanning mechanism compatible with the 22 gauge and 24 gauge hypodermic needles that are required in neonatal and young pediatric vascular access. The disposable needs to integrate into the needle in a manner that does not compromise size, weight, cost and clinical work flow, while providing clinically relevant imaging. Small cross-section OCT probes historically have been either forward-looking with a small field of view or radial (side-firing) optimized for intra-luminal work. Neither of these optical projections are particularly suitable for use in vascular access where the needle approaches the vessel at some angle in the general range of 10 - 50 degrees but with a distinct bias to the smaller end of this range.

To solve this problem the team developed a projection system capable of accommodating a variable range of approach angles in order to acquire data of sufficient quality and resolution for reconstruction of clinically relevant images. This was accomplished by using a translation/rotation set up that was built with our partners at Stanford University and was used to determine the optimal angle for the beam exiting the fiber probe.

Once this angle was determined, the next innovation challenge was to design a fiber-optic enabled insert that is simultaneously (a) small enough in diameter in order to fit into 24G PIV needles, (b) sturdy enough for routine clinical use, (c) biocompatible and sterilizable, and, critically, (d) economical enough for use as a disposable in an already cost-challenged procedure.

Lastly, the optimal actuating mechanism required to generate data for clinically relevant images needed to be determined and built into a handpiece prototype. This non-disposable handpiece connects to the imaging processor and enables the insert within the needle to image. The handpiece was additionally designed to allow translation of the insert out ahead of the IV needle to find the vein atraumatically, and aid in the targeting and optimal cannulation of the vein.

These accomplishments are unique and original and would not have been possible without the support of the NSF Phase I grant.


Last Modified: 10/31/2018
Modified by: Thomas Mowery
